title: An athlete uses physics to shatter world records - Asaf Bar-Yosef

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: What year did Dick Fosbury turn 16?
**Comprehension**: What was the main reason Dick Fosbury's new high jump technique, the Fosbury Flop, was successful?

options.label: A
options.text: It required less strength than the traditional technique.

options.label: B
options.text: It allowed the jumper to divert horizontal velocity to vertical velocity.

options.label: C
options.text: It enabled the jumper to clear higher bars with the same amount of force.

options.label: D
options.text: It made the jumper's body more aerodynamic.

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: If you were a high jumper, how could you use the concept of center of mass to your advantage?

options.label: A
options.text: By trying to lift your center of mass above the bar by a few inches.

options.label: B
options.text: By applying the same amount of force to raise your body higher than before.

options.label: C
options.text: By splitting your body away from your center of mass to give it more room to clear higher bars.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the concept of center of mass altogether.

multiple-choice.question: **Analysis**: What is the relationship between an object's center of mass and its balancing point?

options.label: A
options.text: The center of mass is always above the balancing point.

options.label: B
options.text: The center of mass is always below the balancing point.

options.label: C
options.text: The center of mass is always at the same location as the balancing point.

options.label: D
options.text: The center of mass and balancing point are unrelated.

multiple-choice.question: **Synthesis**: How could you apply the concept of center of mass to a real-world scenario, such as designing a new type of vehicle?

options.label: A
options.text: By placing the center of mass of the vehicle as low as possible to improve stability.

options.label: B
options.text: By placing the center of mass of the vehicle as high as possible to improve visibility.

options.label: C
options.text: By splitting the vehicle's body away from its center of mass to improve maneuverability.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the concept of center of mass altogether.

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: What are the advantages and disadvantages of the Fosbury Flop technique?

options.label: A
options.text: Advantages: enables jumpers to clear higher bars with the same amount of force, disadvantages: requires more strength than traditional techniques.

options.label: B
options.text: Advantages: requires less strength than traditional techniques, disadvantages: enables jumpers to clear lower bars.

options.label: C
options.text: Advantages: enables jumpers to clear higher bars with the same amount of force, disadvantages: requires more flexibility than traditional techniques.

options.label: D
options.text: Advantages: requires less strength than traditional techniques, disadvantages: enables jumpers to clear lower bars.

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: In what year did Dick Fosbury win a gold medal in the Olympic Games?
**Comprehension**: What is the secret behind the Fosbury Flop technique?

options.label: A
options.text: It lies in the jumper's ability to apply more force to the bar.

options.label: B
options.text: It lies in the jumper's ability to clear the bar by a few inches.

options.label: C
options.text: It lies in the jumper's ability to divert horizontal velocity to vertical velocity.

options.label: D
options.text: It lies in the jumper's ability to clear higher bars with the same amount of force.

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: If you were a coach, how could you use the concept of center of mass to help your athletes improve their high jump technique?

options.label: A
options.text: By teaching them to lift their center of mass above the bar by a few inches.

options.label: B
options.text: By teaching them to split their body away from their center of mass to give it more room to clear higher bars.

options.label: C
options.text: By teaching them to apply the same amount of force to raise their body higher than before.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the concept of center of mass altogether.

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: What are the implications of the Fosbury Flop technique on the sport of high jump?

options.label: A
options.text: It has led to a decrease in the number of athletes competing in the high jump.

options.label: B
options.text: It has led to an increase in the number of athletes competing in the high jump.

options.label: C
options.text: It has led to a change in the way athletes approach the high jump, with a focus on clearing higher bars.

options.label: D
options.text: It has led to a change in the equipment used in the high jump, with a focus on making the bar higher.

multiple-choice.question: What motivated the author to spend five years thinking about being wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: To explore the consequences of error blindness and the impact of being wrong on our personal and professional lives

options.label: B
options.text: To develop a new career path

options.label: C
options.text: To study the behavior of people who get stuff wrong

options.label: D
options.text: To understand why we often avoid thinking about being wrong

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the problem with feeling right all the time?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to confidence and self-assurance

options.label: B
options.text: It prevents us from learning from mistakes and prevents us from being open to new ideas and perspectives

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's analogy for how we behave when we're wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: We're like a coyote who keeps running off a cliff without realizing it, until we look down and realize our mistake

options.label: B
options.text: We're like a bird who can fly away from problems

options.label: C
options.text: We're like a person who always makes excuses

options.label: D
options.text: We're like a person who never takes risks

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the typical progression of assumptions we make when someone disagrees with us?

options.label: A
options.text: We assume they're ignorant, then they're right, and finally, they're idiots

options.label: B
options.text: We assume they're right, then they're ignorant, and finally, they're idiots

options.label: C
options.text: We assume they're ignorant, then they're idiots, and finally, they're deliberately distorting the truth

options.label: D
options.text: We assume they're ignorant, then they're idiots, and finally, they're right

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's argument about the nature of human error in human beings?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a fundamental aspect of human nature that allows us to learn and grow, and is a result of our unique capacity for self-awareness and imagination

options.label: B
options.text: It's a defect in the human system that can be eradicated

options.label: C
options.text: It's a result of bad habits or lack of education

options.label: D
options.text: It's a sign of laziness or lack of motivation

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the source of all our productivity and creativity?

options.label: A
options.text: Our ability to be right all the time

options.label: B
options.text: Our obsession with trying to figure things out, which drives our innovation and progress

options.label: C
options.text: Our ability to work well in teams

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's observation about the nature of storytelling?

options.label: A
options.text: Stories are always about being wrong

options.label: B
options.text: Stories are always about being right

options.label: C
options.text: Stories are always about being perfect

options.label: D
options.text: Stories often feature moments of surprise and reversal, which are a result of our capacity for error and imagination

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the purpose of moments of surprise and reversal in storytelling?

options.label: B
options.text: To make the story more believable

options.label: C
options.text: To illustrate the consequences of being wrong

options.label: D
options.text: To make the story more entertaining and to reflect the complexity and uncertainty of real life

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's argument about the importance of being wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a fundamental aspect of human nature that allows us to learn and grow, and is a result of our unique capacity for self-awareness and imagination

options.label: B
options.text: It's a sign of weakness or lack of confidence
